awd_titl_txt: CAREER:   Upon Which Selection Can Act: Quantifying How Mutation and Environment Generate Genotypic & Phenotypic Variation in an Emerging Ecological & Evolutionary Genomic Model
awd_abstract_narration:
Mutation is the ultimate source of genetic variation. Although a great deal of theoretical and applied biology rests on understanding the rate at which it occurs and its effects, few estimates exist and the variation among individuals, populations, and species is largely unknown.  This project will quantify mutation rates and their effects on a genome-wide scale using Daphnia, a group of animals that has long served as a sentinel for population biology, community ecology, and environmental toxicology. The detailed analysis will include estimating mutation rates at multiple scales, including i) among the major categories of mutation which differ in their mechanistic causes, ii) between genomes (mitochondrial and nuclear), and iii) within and between species exhibiting different characteristics.  It will be partnered with an analysis of measurable (phenotypic) effects of mutations on traits such as longevity, growth rate, and fecundity among these same groups and in variable environments.  Special attention will be paid to a particularly exciting source of mutation in the genome-transposable elements. All biological and genomic resources developed will be made publicly available. 

Broader Impacts
Pursuing excellence in research and teaching is often seen as a trade-off, yet strategic approaches can enrich both endeavors.  Knowledge gained from real-life scenarios and hands-on experience is often more compelling with longer lasting impact. These projects will be part of an integrative program of basic research (involving students, post-doctoral researchers, and collaborators), teaching and curriculum development (including the development of new courses and tutorials), and outreach (through domestic and international workshops, as well as public lectures).  The benefits of this research include 1) deepening our understanding of key parameters in biology, 2) generating shared biological, genomic, and bioinformatic resources, 3) building science capacity through collaborating with the next generation of American and international scientists, and 4) educating the public about the central role of genetics, genomics, and evolution by sharing new discoveries as they occur.
org_div_long_name: Division of Molecular and Cellular Biosciences

pgm_ref.pgm_ref_txt: REU SUPP-Res Exp for Ugrd Supp

por.por_cntn:
The goals of this project were to understand the dynamics of spontaneous mutation and their effects on phenotypes. The main experiments were all completed, and numerous side projects stemming from the main experiments offered trainees the opportunity to develop their independence as researchers. In terms of broader impacts, the goal was also to train students and post-docs in next generation sequencing technologies and analyses. Almost 100 trainees benefited from this award, over 400 workshop participants, and over 30 peer-reviewed publications resulted from this work. Our work on this project has uncovered, revised, or challenged numerous fundamental tenets and assumptions about mutation biology, which now require further investigation.

1) Our findings counter previous work relying on estimates of mutation rates from one or a few genotypes, and assuming that those estimates can be extrapolated to represent rates for the entire species (or in some cases genus or order).

2) Our estimates further dismantle any confidence that can be placed in indirect estimates of spontaneous mutation rates which have been, historically, heavily relied upon (especially for species for which mutation accumulation experiments are not feasible or ethical).

3) Our work has led to the development of robust methods for estimating mutation rates for more than just base substitution mutation rates, but instead includes many kinds of mutation types (including indel rates, microsatellite mutation rates, transposable element rates, gene conversion rates, and more).

4) Our estimates of mutation rate variation among mutation types have challenged the long held assumption that base substitution mutation rates are a useful proxy for ALL mutation rates. They do not co-vary with other types of mutation rates, nor are they the most common mutations or the most high impact.

5) Our work on transposable elements, in particular, broke new gorund for this dynamic and oftern-overlooked portion of the genome. Transposable elments represent significant proportions of most eukaryotic genomes, yet investigations of their mutational activity were largely lacking prior to our work.

6) Our estimates of extremely high and highly variable mutation rates among lineages of Daphnia magna have changed the range of mutation rates observed for invertebrate animals, and has led to our next focal question, which is WHAT explains the variation we've observed in mutation rates within this species.

7) Our work on the phenotypic effects of mutation suggest that mutations impact both simple and complex phenotypes, and that the phenotypic effects of mutation may be exacerbated when individuals in which they occur encounter multiple stressors in their environment.

 


Last Modified: 07/05/2023
Modified by: Sarah Schaack
